text: Hey Gwen! I have never posted a preprint on that server, and I am sure you thought of these points before - but for the reporting checklist I figure you could go one of two ways 1)  fill out the consort checklist for clinical trials and include N/A + justification for the criteria that you are not reporting because it’s a secondary analysis of a clinical trial and cite the main report where those features are described or 2) depending on your RQs/analyses, use the STROBE checklist for observational studies or another checklist that fits better, without worrying that it’s a clinical trial. For example, this might work if you are analyzing data cross sectionally within the trial. Personally I think option 1 might be cleaner!

root.text: Does anyone by any chance have experience with posting preprints to MedRxiv? They require you to find and fill out the research reporting checklist deemed most appropriate by the EQUATORS network, which is actually pretty awesome in itself, I just fall into a strange category because I am using data from a clinical trial, but not looking at most of the basic things included in those so I’m having trouble to find the right checklist for me to fill out…

Hey Gwen! I have never posted a preprint on that server, and I am sure you thought of these points before - but for the reporting checklist I figure you could go one of two ways 1)  fill out the consort checklist for clinical trials and include N/A + justification for the criteria that you are not reporting because it’s a secondary analysis of a clinical trial and cite the main report where those features are described or 2) depending on your RQs/analyses, use the STROBE checklist for observational studies or another checklist that fits better, without worrying that it’s a clinical trial. For example, this might work if you are analyzing data cross sectionally within the trial. Personally I think option 1 might be cleaner!
